elements.content: A novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n (HNCP = 2-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazo(4,5-f)(1,10)phenanthroline), synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction between MnSO4 and a new designed multifunctional ligand HNCP, displays a second harmonic generation efficiency that is approximately three times as much as that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP), weak antiferromagnetic character, and strong fluorescence emission with λmax at 588 nm as well as high thermal stability (up to ca. 490 °C).
elements.clean_text: A novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n  (HNCP = 2-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazo(4,5-f)(1,10)phenanthroline), synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction between MnSO4 and a new designed multifunctional ligand HNCP, displays a second harmonic generation efficiency that is approximately three times as much as that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP), weak antiferromagnetic character, and strong fluorescence emission with λmax at 588 nm as well as high thermal stability (up to ca. 490 °C).

elements.content: A novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n (HNCP = 2-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazo(4,5-f)(1,10)phenanthroline) displays efficient SHG response, weak antiferromagnetic character, and strong orange-yello fluorescence emission as well as high thermal stability.
elements.clean_text: A novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n  (HNCP = 2-(4-carboxyphenyl)imidazo(4,5-f)(1,10)phenanthroline) displays efficient SHG response, weak antiferromagnetic character, and strong orange-yello fluorescence emission as well as high thermal stability.

elements.content: The rational design and construction of new coordination polymers based on assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands are an increasingly interesting research field because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in functional materials. A noncentric space group symmetry is a requirement for a number of technologically relevant properties, including piezoelectricity, pyroelectricity, ferroelectricity, and second harmonic generation (SHG). Apparently, the topological structures of the resulting coordination polymer are mostly dependent on the geometry of metal centers and the bonding mode of bridging ligands. Our strategy of rational design and synthesis of noncentric coordination polymers is to employ a new designed long-conjugated unsymmetrical ligand HNCP (as shown in Scheme ) as bridging ligand with phenanthroline nitrogen and carboxylato-oxygen donor atoms in either end to link tetrahedrally connected metal centers and create noncenteric polymeric compounds with robust diamondiod network. On the other hand, it is well-established that diamondoid networks tend to interpenetrate to fill the voids generated within a single diamond net. Even interpenetration could potentially introduce an inversion center, which will complicate the crystal engineering of noncentric solids based on diamondoid networks. We demonstrate in this communication construction of a noncentric coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n (1) with odd (7-fold) interpenetrating diamondoid nets, along with its nonlinear optical (NLO), magnetic, and luminescence properties. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported coordination polymer that combines SHG response, magnetic character, and strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: The rational design and construction of new coordination polymers based on assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands are an increasingly interesting research field because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in functional materials. A noncentric space group symmetry is a requirement for a number of technologically relevant properties, including piezoelectricity, pyroelectricity, ferroelectricity, and second harmonic generation (SHG). Apparently, the topological structures of the resulting coordination polymer are mostly dependent on the geometry of metal centers and the bonding mode of bridging ligands. Our strategy of rational design and synthesis of noncentric coordination polymers is to employ a new designed long-conjugated unsymmetrical ligand HNCP (as shown in Scheme )  as bridging ligand with phenanthroline nitrogen and carboxylato-oxygen donor atoms in either end to link tetrahedrally connected metal centers and create noncenteric polymeric compounds with robust diamondiod network. On the other hand, it is well-established that diamondoid networks tend to interpenetrate to fill the voids generated within a single diamond net. Even interpenetration could potentially introduce an inversion center, which will complicate the crystal engineering of noncentric solids based on diamondoid networks. We demonstrate in this communication construction of a noncentric coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n  (1) with odd (7-fold) interpenetrating diamondoid nets, along with its nonlinear optical (NLO), magnetic, and luminescence properties. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported coordination polymer that combines SHG response, magnetic character, and strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission in the solid state.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Structure and Synthetic Route of HNCP</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gs1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2007-00192a_0001.tif" xlink:type="simple"></graphic>
</fig>
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure and Synthetic Route of HNCP

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized hydrothermally by treating MnSO4 and HNCP at 180 °C. All major peaks of experimental powder X-ray pattern (XRPD) of compound 1 match quite well with that of the simulated XRPD, indicating reasonable crystalline phase purity. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement showed that 1 has excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 490 °C.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was synthesized hydrothermally by treating MnSO4 and HNCP at 180 °C. All major peaks of experimental powder X-ray pattern (XRPD) of compound 1 match quite well with that of the simulated XRPD, indicating reasonable crystalline phase purity. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurement showed that 1 has excellent thermal stability, as no strictly clean weight loss step occurred below 490 °C.

elements.content: The three-dimensional polymeric structure of 1 was revealed by an X-ray single crystal diffraction investigation. As shown in Figure , the coordination geometry of Mn(II) is a distorted octahedron completed by four phenanthroline nitrogen atoms from two different NCP− in bidentate chelating mode and two carboxylato-oxygen atoms from two other NCP− in monodentate mode. If the two chelating nitrogen atoms are treated as one connecting point, the Mn center also has a pseudotetrahedral environment. Two geometric topologies of 3D diamondiod network and 7-fold interpenetration nets are shown in panels a and b in Figure , respectively. Each Mn center is connected to four Mn centers through NCP− to form a three-dimensional diamondoid-like net (Figure a). Each NCP− links two Mn centers with Mn···Mn separation of 16.19 Å. Mn···Mn···Mn angles are in the range of 101.6–123.2°, which represents a significant distortion from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° found in diamond and thus causes lower symmetry compared with diamond. With a Mn···Mn separation of 16.19 Å, a large void is generated within a single diamondiod cage. The large void space is filled by the other six diamondoid polymeric structures (Figure b), resulting in 7-fold mutually interpenetrating diamondoid nets in which strong hydrogen-bonding interactions (as shown in Figure . N3#1···O2 2.720(4) Å. symmetry code: #1 x + 1/2, –y + 1, z – 1/2) between an N–H group in the imidazole ring and an uncoordinated carboxylato-oxygen atom play a key role in the final recognition process. The π–π attractions between the phenylimidazole derivative and phenanthroline derivative of NCP− (as shown in Figure , the centroid–centroid distance is about 3.5 Å) also take effect on the packing of 1. As a result of the unsymmetrical nature of NCP− and the 7-fold penetration, 1 crystallizes in the noncentric space group Aba2.
elements.clean_text: The three-dimensional polymeric structure of 1 was revealed by an X-ray single crystal diffraction investigation. As shown in Figure , the coordination geometry of Mn(II) is a distorted octahedron completed by four phenanthroline nitrogen atoms from two different NCP- in bidentate chelating mode and two carboxylato-oxygen atoms from two other NCP- in monodentate mode. If the two chelating nitrogen atoms are treated as one connecting point, the Mn center also has a pseudotetrahedral environment. Two geometric topologies of 3D diamondiod network and 7-fold interpenetration nets are shown in panels a and b in Figure , respectively. Each Mn center is connected to four Mn centers through NCP- to form a three-dimensional diamondoid-like net (Figure a). Each NCP- links two Mn centers with Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separation of 16.19 Å. Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn angles are in the range of 101.6-123.2°, which represents a significant distortion from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° found in diamond and thus causes lower symmetry compared with diamond. With a Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separation of 16.19 Å, a large void is generated within a single diamondiod cage. The large void space is filled by the other six diamondoid polymeric structures (Figure b), resulting in 7-fold mutually interpenetrating diamondoid nets in which strong hydrogen-bonding interactions (as shown in Figure . N3#1⋅⋅⋅O2 2.720(4) Å. symmetry code: #1 x + 1/2, -y + 1, z - 1/2) between an N-H group in the imidazole ring and an uncoordinated carboxylato-oxygen atom play a key role in the final recognition process. The π-π attractions between the phenylimidazole derivative and phenanthroline derivative of NCP- (as shown in Figure , the centroid-centroid distance is about 3.5 Å) also take effect on the packing of 1. As a result of the unsymmetrical nature of NCP- and the 7-fold penetration, 1 crystallizes in the noncentric space group Aba2.

elements.content: Coordination environment of Mn(II), bonding mode of NCP−, π–π attraction (black dash line), and hydrogen bond (red dash line) in coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2]n(1). Selected bond lengths (μ): Mn–N(1) 2.303(3), Mn–N(2) 2.400(3), Mn–O(1) 2.153(2). Symmetry code: #1 x + 1/2, –y + 1, z – 1/2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment of Mn(II), bonding mode of NCP-, π-π attraction (black dash line), and hydrogen bond (red dash line) in coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2]n(1). Selected bond lengths (μ): Mn-N(1) 2.303(3), Mn-N(2) 2.400(3), Mn-O(1) 2.153(2). Symmetry code: #1 x + 1/2, -y + 1, z - 1/2.

elements.content: (a) 3D diamondlike polymeric network (circles and straight lines represent Mn atoms and NCP− ligands, respectively). The other six interpenetrating diamandoid nets are omitted for clarity. (b) 2D 7-fold interpenetrating diamondoid nets, with one net highlighted with red color.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 3D diamondlike polymeric network (circles and straight lines represent Mn atoms and NCP- ligands, respectively). The other six interpenetrating diamandoid nets are omitted for clarity. (b) 2D 7-fold interpenetrating diamondoid nets, with one net highlighted with red color.

elements.content: Second-order nonlinear optical effect for microcrystalline of 1 has been investigated by optical second harmonic generation (SHG) on the basis of the principles proposed by Kurtz and Perry. The intensity of green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by microcrystalline 1 is approximately three times as much as that produced by a KDP power, which confirm the acentricity of 1. The molecular static hyperpolaribility (β0) of HNCP upon optimized geometry was calculated with the B3LYP/6–31+G(D) method in the Gaussion 03 suite of programs, giving large β0 = 65 × 10−30 esu. However, the powder of ligand HNCP does not display a SHG response, probably because of its centric array in the solid state. The SHG response of compound 1 is realized by noncentric array of NCP− through Mn centers. Thus, compound 1 combines the advantages of both pure organic and inorganic NLO materials, and such hybrid inorganic–organic NLO materials have recently been widely investigated as NLO materials.
elements.clean_text: Second-order nonlinear optical effect for microcrystalline of 1 has been investigated by optical second harmonic generation (SHG) on the basis of the principles proposed by Kurtz and Perry. The intensity of green light (frequency-doubled output: 532 nm) produced by microcrystalline 1 is approximately three times as much as that produced by a KDP power, which confirm the acentricity of 1. The molecular static hyperpolaribility (β0) of HNCP upon optimized geometry was calculated with the B3LYP/6-31+G(D) method in the Gaussion 03 suite of programs, giving large β0 = 65 × 10-30 esu. However, the powder of ligand HNCP does not display a SHG response, probably because of its centric array in the solid state. The SHG response of compound 1 is realized by noncentric array of NCP- through Mn centers. Thus, compound 1 combines the advantages of both pure organic and inorganic NLO materials, and such hybrid inorganic-organic NLO materials have recently been widely investigated as NLO materials.

elements.content: The magnetic property of 1 has been studied over the temperature range 2–300 K. The temperature dependence of [graphic1] m and [graphic2] m −1 is shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility obeys the Curie–Weiss law and gives a Curie constant (C) of 3.9 cm3 K mol−1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of −5.9 K. The value of C is lower than the spin-only value of 4.4 cm3 K mol−1 for one high-spin MnII ion (g = 2, S = 5/2) assuming no magnetic interaction. Such behavior shows overall weak antiferromagnetic character of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic property of 1 has been studied over the temperature range 2-300 K. The temperature dependence of [graphic1] m  and [graphic2] m  -1 is shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility obeys the Curie-Weiss law and gives a Curie constant (C) of 3.9 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of -5.9 K. The value of C is lower than the spin-only value of 4.4 cm3 K mol-1 for one high-spin MnII ion (g = 2, S = 5/2) assuming no magnetic interaction. Such behavior shows overall weak antiferromagnetic character of compound 1.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm (○) and χm −1 (□) for 1
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of χm (○) and χm -1 (□) for 1

elements.content: The other important feature of 1 is that its three-dimensionally condensed polymeric structure gives rise to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity, which is larger than that of free ligand HNCP by a factor of ca. 10, probably because of the enhanced rigidity of 1 compared to the free ligand. Figure shows the emission spectrum of compound 1. Irradiated by UV light at ambient temperature, a broad emission band in the range of 500–750 nm with λmax at 588 nm was observed. In addition, the decay lifetime of 1 was measured to be 8.9 ns. The long-wavelength emission of 1 is neither MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) nor LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) in nature and can probably be assigned to intraligand fluorescence emission, because a weaker emission with λmax at 581 nm was also observed for HNCP. The strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission and high stability of 1 suggest that it may be used as an emitter for an electroluminescence device or as potential material for a light-emitting diode device.
elements.clean_text: The other important feature of 1 is that its three-dimensionally condensed polymeric structure gives rise to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity, which is larger than that of free ligand HNCP by a factor of ca. 10, probably because of the enhanced rigidity of 1 compared to the free ligand. Figure  shows the emission spectrum of compound 1. Irradiated by UV light at ambient temperature, a broad emission band in the range of 500-750 nm with λmax at 588 nm was observed. In addition, the decay lifetime of 1 was measured to be 8.9 ns. The long-wavelength emission of 1 is neither MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) nor LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) in nature and can probably be assigned to intraligand fluorescence emission, because a weaker emission with λmax at 581 nm was also observed for HNCP. The strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission and high stability of 1 suggest that it may be used as an emitter for an electroluminescence device or as potential material for a light-emitting diode device.

elements.content: Emission spectra of HNCP (black line, upon excitation at 370 nm) and compound 1 (red line, upon excitation at 415nm) in solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  Emission spectra of HNCP (black line, upon excitation at 370 nm) and compound 1 (red line, upon excitation at 415nm) in solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, a novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer based on assembly of Mn(II) and NCP− has been revealed. The condensed coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n (1) with special topology appears to be an excellent candidate for multifunctional material because, in addition to its high thermal stability, it is virtually insoluble in most solvents such as H2O, CH3OH, CH2Cl2, CH3COCH3, CH3CN, THF, DMF, and DMSO.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel 7-fold interpenetration diamondoid network neutral coordination polymer based on assembly of Mn(II) and NCP- has been revealed. The condensed coordination polymer [Mn(NCP)2] n  (1) with special topology appears to be an excellent candidate for multifunctional material because, in addition to its high thermal stability, it is virtually insoluble in most solvents such as H2O, CH3OH, CH2Cl2, CH3COCH3, CH3CN, THF, DMF, and DMSO.

elements.content: 1H NMR (DMSO) of the ligand HNCP·2.5H2O, experimental and simulated XRPDs of the compound 1, thermogravimetric analysis for the compound 1 (Word); CIF file for the compound 1. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: 1H NMR (DMSO) of the ligand HNCP⋅2.5H2O, experimental and simulated XRPDs of the compound 1, thermogravimetric analysis for the compound 1 (Word); CIF file for the compound 1. This information is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Preparation of HNCP·2.5H2O: A mixture of 2 mmol 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione, 2.2mmol 4-carboxybenzaldehyde, 15 mL of glacial acetic acid, and 3.2 g f ammonium acetate in a 100 mL flask with a condenser was refluxed for 2 h, resulting in a yellow precipitate. After cooling, the mixture was diluted with 25 mL of water and the pH value of the solution was adjusted with concentrated aqueous ammonia to 5.5. The yellow product was filtered from the mixture and washed with water and acetone, oven-dried at 60°C (yield: 87% based on 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione). Mp: 305–307 °C. Anal. Calcd for HNCP·2.5H2O: C, 62.33; H, 4.45; N, 14.54; O, 18.68. Found: C, 62.41; H, 4.38; N, 14.58; O, 18.61. 1H NMR (DMSO): 9.05 d 2H, 8.96 d 2H, 8.42 d 2H, 8.19 d 2H, 7.85 dd 2H. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3434b, 1615s, 1540m, 1478w, 1451w, 1398s, 1262w, 1071w, 960w, 860w, 838w, 806m, 779w, 732m, 709m.
elements.clean_text:
References

Preparation of HNCP⋅2.5H2O: A mixture of 2 mmol 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione, 2.2mmol 4-carboxybenzaldehyde, 15 mL of glacial acetic acid, and 3.2 g f ammonium acetate in a 100 mL flask with a condenser was refluxed for 2 h, resulting in a yellow precipitate. After cooling, the mixture was diluted with 25 mL of water and the pH value of the solution was adjusted with concentrated aqueous ammonia to 5.5. The yellow product was filtered from the mixture and washed with water and acetone, oven-dried at 60°C (yield: 87% based on 1,10-phenanthroline-5,6-dione). Mp: 305-307 °C. Anal. Calcd for HNCP⋅2.5H2O: C, 62.33; H, 4.45; N, 14.54; O, 18.68. Found: C, 62.41; H, 4.38; N, 14.58; O, 18.61. 1H NMR (DMSO): 9.05 d 2H, 8.96 d 2H, 8.42 d 2H, 8.19 d 2H, 7.85 dd 2H. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3434b, 1615s, 1540m, 1478w, 1451w, 1398s, 1262w, 1071w, 960w, 860w, 838w, 806m, 779w, 732m, 709m.

elements.content: Preparation of [Mn(NCP)2] n (1): hydrothermal treatment of MnSO4 (0.3 mmol), HNCP·2.5H2O (0.5 mmol) and H2O (25 mL) in an autoclave at 180 °C for 3 days gave orange crystals of 1 (yield: 85% based on HNCP). Anal. Calcd for Mn1C40H22N8O4: C, 65.49; H, 3.02; N, 15.27; O, 8.72. Found: C, 65.43; H, 3.06; N, 15.21; O, 8.78. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3435br, 1597s, 1535m, 1475w, 1449w, 1389s, 1274w, 1069m, 948w, 877w, 838w, 806m, 776m, 731m, 717m. Crystal data for compound 1: fw 733.60, orthorhombic, Aba2, a = 15.4071(12) Å, b= 20.450(2) Å, c = 9.9044(10) Å, V = 3120.6(5), Z = 4, ρcalcd = 1.561 g cm−3, μ = 0.485 mm−1, R1/wR2 = 0.0467/0.1106 (I > 2σ) and 0.0598/0.1189 (all data), Flack parameter value χ = 0.04(3).

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic property of 1 has been studied over the temperature range 2–300 K. The temperature dependence of [graphic1] m and [graphic2] m −1 is shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility obeys the Curie–Weiss law and gives a Curie constant (C) of 3.9 cm3 K mol−1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of −5.9 K. The value of C is lower than the spin-only value of 4.4 cm3 K mol−1 for one high-spin MnII ion (g = 2, S = 5/2) assuming no magnetic interaction. Such behavior shows overall weak antiferromagnetic character of compound 1.

The other important feature of 1 is that its three-dimensionally condensed polymeric structure gives rise to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity, which is larger than that of free ligand HNCP by a factor of ca. 10, probably because of the enhanced rigidity of 1 compared to the free ligand. Figure shows the emission spectrum of compound 1. Irradiated by UV light at ambient temperature, a broad emission band in the range of 500–750 nm with λmax at 588 nm was observed. In addition, the decay lifetime of 1 was measured to be 8.9 ns. The long-wavelength emission of 1 is neither MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) nor LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) in nature and can probably be assigned to intraligand fluorescence emission, because a weaker emission with λmax at 581 nm was also observed for HNCP. The strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission and high stability of 1 suggest that it may be used as an emitter for an electroluminescence device or as potential material for a light-emitting diode device.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The magnetic property of 1 has been studied over the temperature range 2-300 K. The temperature dependence of [graphic1] m  and [graphic2] m  -1 is shown in Figure . The magnetic susceptibility obeys the Curie-Weiss law and gives a Curie constant (C) of 3.9 cm3 K mol-1 and a Weiss constant (θ) of -5.9 K. The value of C is lower than the spin-only value of 4.4 cm3 K mol-1 for one high-spin MnII ion (g = 2, S = 5/2) assuming no magnetic interaction. Such behavior shows overall weak antiferromagnetic character of compound 1.

The other important feature of 1 is that its three-dimensionally condensed polymeric structure gives rise to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity, which is larger than that of free ligand HNCP by a factor of ca. 10, probably because of the enhanced rigidity of 1 compared to the free ligand. Figure  shows the emission spectrum of compound 1. Irradiated by UV light at ambient temperature, a broad emission band in the range of 500-750 nm with λmax at 588 nm was observed. In addition, the decay lifetime of 1 was measured to be 8.9 ns. The long-wavelength emission of 1 is neither MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) nor LMCT (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) in nature and can probably be assigned to intraligand fluorescence emission, because a weaker emission with λmax at 581 nm was also observed for HNCP. The strong orange-yellow fluorescence emission and high stability of 1 suggest that it may be used as an emitter for an electroluminescence device or as potential material for a light-emitting diode device.
